stream_context.summary: Brain-storming session for Overworld 3; Course 11 (Frantic Fleet Factory) chosen and fully outlined while larger level line-up for the last world is finalised. Bowser fight logic complete; waiting on Zeina’s animations. Kaze tests performance and discusses technical targets.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 officially titled "Frantic Fleet Factory" and replaces earlier 'minion training ground' idea.
Factory narrative: Bowser’s troops build airships; Mario sabotages the plant through staged ‘work-place pranks’ that trigger a strike and boss encounter.
development_findings.quote: The goal for Mario is to sabotage the building. After every mess up, you have an overseer get more upset and he turns red.

development_findings.summary: Detailed star plan for Course 11 includes five sabotage set-pieces (seesaw, thwomp dominoes, cement footprints, glass pane smash, oil barrel slip), a crane sequence that topples a Bowser statue, a strike-breaking boss, and a construction-beam red-coin area.
Enemies will wear helmets so jump attacks fail, providing an in-world explanation for non-lethal stomp mechanics.
development_findings.quote: We have to give the player some kind of explanation why jumping on them doesn't kill them.

development_findings.summary: Planned set pieces: half-built house of breakable blocks, office window cameo of furious Bowser, cannons linking buildings, numerous cranes, scaffolding and demolition zones.
Bowser fight logic finished; only animations, SFX and VFX left before it is complete.
development_findings.quote: The Bowser fight is basically finished… we are waiting for Zeina's animation first before I implement all that.

development_findings.summary: Performance on real N64 hardware now stays above 30 FPS even in widescreen; Kaze’s new 20 FPS interpolation can’t be demonstrated because the game no longer drops that low.
development_findings.quote: I can't even get below 30 FPS… the performance here is just way too good.

development_findings.summary: Final Overworld 3 course themes selected: Frantic Fleet Factory, Wild West Valley (detective outlaw hunt), Super-hero Comic City with mirror-world Raven dimension, Music/Composer playground (Mario Paint style), and Casino with Dr Mario retro pipe.
Computer-themed level and Bowser Minion Training Ground ideas officially scrapped.
Retro pipe assignments finalised: Factory→Smash 64 Board, West Valley→Paper Mario 64, Comic City→Mario Land 1, Casino→Dr Mario, Music Level→Mario Paint.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: generate more ideas than needed ("come up with 15 ideas and use 5") and prioritise decisions over raw asset production.
context_findings.quote: No matter how hard you work, if you don't make good decisions, your game's gonna be shit.

context_findings.summary: Prefers clear, easily understood mechanics; rejects overly abstract or ‘too weeb’ concepts and discourages repeated chat requests.
context_findings.quote: The thing about games is, it's good to have a complex game as long as it's easy to understand.

context_findings.summary: Moved streaming to YouTube due to excessive Twitch ads; willing to accept smaller viewer counts for better experience.
context_findings.quote: Yeah, I'm streaming on YouTube now… It's the better long-term decision, I think.

context_findings.summary: Targets only NTSC builds; has no plans to support PAL hardware.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions Biobak could handle large art tasks (e.g., steampunk assets) but doesn’t want to impose unpaid workload.
biobak.quote: I'm not just gonna ask Biobak, hey, just do like 200 hours of unpaid labor for me, please.

badub.summary: Interactive music level will require coordination with Badub for adaptive/mini-composition mechanics.
badub.quote: It's going to be difficult to organize this with Badub, but I think it should work.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating Bowser fight animations, a dependency blocking VFX/SFX integration.
zeina.quote: We're now waiting for the animations Zeina's making… then we're doing the VFX and SFX.

key_stories.title: From Idea Drought to Five-Course Line-up
key_stories.summary: Kaze realises they only have seven ideas for eight remaining slots and launches a live brainstorming session with chat. Over two hours they debate, merge and discard concepts until a definitive five-course plan emerges for Overworld 3.
key_stories.challenge: Not enough high-quality level themes for the final world.
key_stories.process: Rapid-fire chat suggestions, thematic tests against Yoshi’s Island tone, rejection of repeats, merging of compatible ideas.
key_stories.outcome: Final list: Frantic Fleet Factory, Wild West Valley, Super-Hero Comic/Mirror City, Music Composer Level, Casino with Dr Mario retro pipe.

key_stories.title: Designing Frantic Fleet Factory
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines every star objective, environmental asset and narrative beat for Course 11, transforming an abstract ‘airship factory’ idea into a full mission structure.
key_stories.challenge: Replace abandoned ‘minion training ground’ with a compelling factory level.
key_stories.process: Defines sabotage gags, strike narrative, crane topple set-piece, boss fight, construction red-coin route, breakable house, Bowser office cameo.
key_stories.outcome: Comprehensive design document ready for 3D block-out.

key_stories.title: Boss Fight Finished—But Animation Pending
key_stories.summary: Logic for Bowser’s new fight is coded and demoed, but the encounter can’t be final until Zeina supplies animations and Kaze adds effects.
key_stories.process: Kaze programs mechanics and tests on stream; highlights need for parachuting enemies, Yoshi ships, fade-out damage tweak.
key_stories.outcome: Waiting on Zeina’s work before final polish; fight otherwise completed.
key_stories.key_quote: The Bowser fight is basically finished. It just needs animations, sound effects and visual effects.

open_questions.context: High-level design finished, but minute-to-minute gameplay, specific strike-breaker boss, and breakable house tech are undecided.
questions: What enemy will serve as the strike-breaker boss and how will its mechanics differ?
How will the breakable block house be optimised for N64 hardware?
How will helmeted enemies communicate immunity to stomps without frustrating players?

open_questions.context: Concept of switching between bright superhero city and low-gravity raven ‘dark world’ via mirrors was sketched but not technically specified.
questions: What engine tricks will enable real-time mirror portals on N64?
How will gravity and physics differ between worlds?
What cues will guide players to use mirrors strategically?

open_questions.context: Plan to let players jump on 12 pitch platforms that emit sounds; coordination with Badub required.
questions: Will notes be quantised to tempo or purely spatial?
Can multiple players or speedrunners create recognizable tunes?
How will memory limits be handled for dynamic samples?

open_questions.context: Zeina’s work is a bottleneck for Bowser fight and potentially other character animations.
questions: What is Zeina’s workflow and toolchain for N64-compatible animations?
How do Kaze and Zeina review and iterate on anim states?
Is there a schedule to prevent future animation bottlenecks?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions new interpolation technique but no longer hits 20 FPS on hardware.
questions: How does the interpolation system work and will it be kept for rare slowdowns?
What specific optimisations achieved this new performance headroom?
Will PAL users still need separate timing adjustments?
